``` ## Daily schedule - **Breakfast** (9 - 9:30AM) - **Morning:** Math (9:30AM - noon) - **Lunch:** Meet faculty, students (noon - 1PM) - **Break** (1 - 1:30PM) - **Afternoon:** R programming (1:30 - 4PM) ::: aside See [gustavodiaz.org/NUmathcamp](https://gustavodiaz.org/NUmathcamp/) for content :::: ## Learning goals ::: incremental - Make you feel very stressed about things you are supposed to already know - Me saying "I told you this was important" in five years - Confront your fears about math early on - So that you can do the cool things with confidence - (The fear never goes away, but you learn to live with it) ::: ## Expectations ::: incremental - You are not being evaluated - No need to take extensive notes - Bring a laptop - Engage - Get things wrong - Ask - Interrupt if you need to ::: ## Some notes ::: incremental - Class is not graded, but you will get credit for attending (POLI_SCI 490) - Content is cumulative (now and forever) - Everyone comes in with different experiences and background. This is a feature, not a bug ::: ## Tips on being a grad student ::: incremental - Read the material, learn to be strategic about it, come up with things to discuss - People around you are colleagues, not competition. Treat everyone with respect (including yourself) - Nobody knows what is going on, most people will help you figure things out - There is life beyond grad school ::: # Questions? # Break # Getting in the mindset ## Why do I need mathcamp? You are being trained to become a producer of **scientific knowledge** . . . **Science:** Knowledge generation through falsification . . . **Falsification:** Trying to prove *ourselves* wrong ## Scientific method 1. Puzzle/question 2. Theory/model 3. Hypothesis/implications 4. Observation/testing 5. Conclusion/evaluation . . . Your job will be to become good at *proposing* and *testing* **theories** ::: {style="text-align: center"} ## What is a theory? {.center} ::: ::: {style="text-align: center"} ## What is a theory? {.center} ### ¯\\_(ツ)_/¯ ::: ::: {style="text-align: center"} ## What is a theory? {.center} ### ¯\\_(ツ)_/¯ I have no idea ::: ::: {style="text-align: center"} ## What is a theory? {.center} ### ¯\\_(ツ)_/¯ I have no idea ::: {style="font-size: 80%;"} My *theory* is that no one really knows ::: ::: ::: {style="text-align: center"} ## What is a theory? {.center} ### ¯\\_(ツ)_/¯ I have no idea ::: {style="font-size: 80%;"} My *theory* is that no one really knows ::: ::: {style="font-size: 60%;"} so they make it complicated ::: ::: ::: {style="text-align: center"} ## What is a theory? {.center} ### ¯\\_(ツ)_/¯ I have no idea ::: {style="font-size: 80%;"} My *theory* is that no one really knows ::: ::: {style="font-size: 60%;"} so they make it complicated ::: ::: {style="font-size: 40%;"} and that's why you need a PhD to do it well ::: ::: ## But it sure is important! . . . Most common reasons why a peer-reviewed journal rejects an article: ::: incremental 1. Having no theory 2. Weak theory 3. Insufficient theoretical innovation ::: . . . If you ask me, theory is **logical explanation** or **informed speculation** . . . ::: {style="font-size: 60%;"} (but I am not the right person to ask) ::: ## The important part ::: incremental - Cannot *test* theories because they **unambiguously true or false** - Need to **believe** a theory is true to engage with it scientifically - Instead, test **arguments** that follow from a theory (hypotheses/implications) ::: . . . Sounds like splitting hairs, but there is a good reason for this ## Example ![](img/nu_sing_study.png){fig-align="center" width="90%"} ::: aside https://news.northwestern.edu/stories/2025/04/virtual-singing-brings-connection-and-joy-to-isolated-older-adults-study-finds/ ::: ## Details > In collaboration with Illinois-based Sounds Good Choir, the study assessed the feasibility of virtual group singing for adults over 55 — including those with neurocognitive disorders like dementia — during the COVID-19 pandemic when older adults were experiencing health declines due to isolation. It found virtual group singing can be an effective tool for promoting well-being and social connection during isolation. ::: aside https://doi.org/10.1177/13872877251333155 ::: ## Findings > Participants in the group choir during the pandemic consistently described the activity as providing a sense of normalcy amid widespread disruption — a theme that emerged prominently and merits further investigation. . . . > This suggests that such interventions may help restore a feeling of normalcy, supporting psychological well-being and offering a means of reconnecting with a stable sense of self. ::: aside https://doi.org/10.1177/13872877251333155 ::: ## Breaking it apart . . . **Question:** Can singing help overcome isolation? . . . **Theory:** Choral singing is a therapeutic activity for individuals with neurological disorders . . . **Hypothesis:** Individuals who sing in a choir will report higher levels of well-being than those who do not . . . **Test:** Organize virtual group choir, ask survey questions in the end . . . **Conclusion:** "Isolated older adults find joy and connection through virtual singing" . . . ## Limitations? . . . **Ideal study** . . . Observe person $i$'s well-being with and without singing, everything else constant . . . **Actual study** - Adults 55 an older in Chicago - Elected to participate - Two teleconferencing programs - 176 survey responses out of 695 participants ## Problem . . . Cannot observe the ideal counterfactual . . . Any test/evidence can only be **suggestive** . . . - When evidence supports hypothesis, your theory is ~~accepted~~ **not rejected** - When evidence does not support hypothesis, your theory is ~~rejected~~ **not accepted** . . . Connecting from narrow findings to broad theories requires **assumptions** ## Statistics Is all about acknowledging this gap and making assumptions *explicit, systematic, and credible* ::: incremental - **Math** is a tool that helps us translate across domains - The difficulty lies mostly in embracing the *abstraction* - Less so on notation, symbols, operations ::: ## Frequently asked questions . . . Do I need mathcamp if... ::: incremental - I already have training in quantitative methods? - I plan to use qualitative methods only? - I am in political theory? - I want a teaching job? - I am considering non-academic jobs? ::: # Questions?

<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
